Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Phylogenomics of Anthozoa (Cnidaria): new approaches to long-standing problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Worldwide, humans and countless other species are dependent on coral reefs for shelter, sustenance and livelihoods. Increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide is causing the world's oceans to become warmer and more acidic, a chemical change that may prevent corals from forming calcium carbonate skeletons. The fossil record indicates, however, that some groups of corals have survived similar environmental crises in past geological eras, and that changes in ocean chemistry may result in the evolution of different types of skeletons or of corals that lack skeletons. Understanding these past evolutionary transitions and the environmental conditions under which they occurred may help scientists predict the responses of today's reef-building corals to future climate change. This collaborative project between researchers from Harvey Mudd College, a Principally Undergraduate Institution, and the American Museum of Natural History will investigate the evolution of calcium carbonate skeletons in Anthozoa (corals, sea anemones, and relatives). They will first generate an extensive time-calibrated molecular phylogeny of the group and then use this evolutionary framework to study the evolution of skeletal characters. Students from groups underrepresented in the sciences will participate in this research through the PI's mentoring of undergraduates at the minority-serving New York City College of Technology, and the Scripps College Academy, a program for high school girls in the Los Angeles area. The project will also generate diverse outreach materials for a public display on corals at the American Museum of Natural History.

Although previous molecular phylogenetic studies have found strong support for relationships among some orders of Anthozoa, key regions of the tree remain poorly resolved, impeding efforts to understand character evolution within the group. By first sequencing complete genomes from eight distantly related taxa of Anthozoa researchers will then design a set of Ultra-Conserved Elements (UCEs) that can be used throughout Anthozoa. UCE sequences will then be generated for 192 Anthozoa species spanning diversity within the group to generate the first phylogenomic estimate of relationships within the group. The researchers will then use this phylogenetic tree and a diverse set of comparative methods to infer the direction, timing and paleoclimatic correlates of evolutionary transitions in skeletogenesis and other traits within the clade that have allowed anthozoans to engineer the largest biological structures on the planet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Corals, sea anemones and relatives make up an important and diverse group of marine invertebrates inhabiting our oceans, the anthozoans. Worldwide, humans and countless other species dependent on coral reefs for shelter, sustenance and livelihoods. However, increasing atmospheric CO2 is causing the world's oceans to become warmer and more acidic, a chemical change that may prevent corals from forming the calcium carbonate (CaCO3) skeletons that form the coral reefs. The future of coral reefs and the diverse species they support will be in jeopardy if corals are no longer able to produce the skeletons forming the physical structure of the reef. However, we know based on fossils that in the past some groups of corals have survived similar environmental crises, and that changes in ocean chemistry may have resulted in the evolution of different types of skeletons or of corals that lack skeletons. Understanding the environmental conditions when these past evolutionary changes occurred may help scientists predict the responses of today's reef-building corals to future climate change. We developed the molecular tools necessary to sequence hundreds of genes from anthozoans, and used these data to construct the first comprehensive, time-calibrated evolutionary tree for the group. Using this evolutionary tree showing the relationships among different groups of anthozoans, we determined when and under what paleoclimate conditions different types of coral skeletons have evolved or been lost over geological time.

We designed a set of RNA probes for target-enrichment of ~1800 conserved regions of the anthozoan genome using published and unpublished genome and transcriptome data. These probes allow variable regions of the genome flanking the conserved regions to be sequenced and compared among distantly related species. Data from 1,729 regions of genome sequenced were used to construct an evolutionary tree for 234 representative anthozoans, and information from the fossil record was used to time-calibrate the tree (estimate when in geological time particular groups first appeared). Our results revealed that anthozoans evolved 250 million years (Ma) before the first confirmed physical evidence of their existence in the fossil record, about 770 Ma. The earliest anthozoans were solitary animals without skeletons, similar to the living tube anemones. Anthozoans first evolved skeletons of CaCO3 in the Cambrian (~500 Ma) during paleoclimate conditions that favored the formation of the calcite form of this mineral. Modern-day reef-building corals with skeletons of the aragonite form of CaCO3 appeared and diversified following a change in paleo-oceanographic conditions to favor the formation of aragonite over calcite, ~380 Ma ago. Colonial forms and symbiotic relationships with photosynthetic microorganisms (traits associated with reef-building) have been gained and lost independently multiple times in different groups of anthozoans since they first appear in the Ediacaran (578 Ma) and Carboniferous (383 Ma), respectively.

Our data showed that reef-building corals with aragonite skeletons have survived several periods of mass extinction (so-called "reef crises") during which paleoclimate conditions were not favoring the formation of aragonite and a majority of species went extinct. However, each of these extinction events was followed by increased rates of diversification of other groups of anthozoans that either lacked a skeleton (e.g. anemones), or had skeletons largely made of proteinaceous material (e.g. sea fans) that could be produced under the prevailing ocean chemistry conditions. These past events suggest that under current climate change scenarios we may expect reef-building corals with aragonite skeletons to suffer high rates of extinction, but they will be replaced by other anthozoan groups such as sea fans and anemones that have diversified following past reef crises.

As broader impacts of this project, additional sets of RNA probes proven to resolve species- and population-level relationships among corals and anemones have been developed and made available for the international research community; this was a much needed molecular tool for the group allowing the study of previously unapproachable questions. The post-doctoral scholar (female, first-generation college student) trained by this award has been hired as the curator of corals at the Smithsonian Institution. Nine undergraduates (6 females, 3 URMs) were supported to conduct independent research associated with this project; five are co-authors of publications resulting from this work and four presented their work at regional conferences. Two additional postdoctoral fellows were trained in bioinformatics of sequence-capture data analysis and its by products; one graduate female also worked on the by products of this project; five high school girls participated in mentored research projects through the HMC Upward Bound and Scripps College Academy programs for underserved schools in Los Angeles to attend college. Eleven additional undergraduates from a NYC community college were mentored in research related with the project. This project has been featured in multiple outreach venues developed and designed mainly at the American Museum of Natural History to reach out to different groups of the public about marine communities, the valuable services they provide, and the environmental challenges they face.
